[h1] R.E.P.O.; the most funniest game when playing with friends, yet quite a good scary one when playing solo [/h1]

[b] Note before you read: Those are my personal opinions and views of the Game. [/b]

Repo is, next to Lethal Company, one of the most funniest but also quite the most horrifying multiplayer game when playing with friends and solo. Multiplayer.. obviously the horror gets replaced with lots of funny moments with your friends, but when playing solo, it has quite a chilling atmosphere and with mods (love that the devs openly support mods, that's so awesome) even a lot more better!

[h3] Graphics and Atmosphere [/h3]

Similar like in Lethal Company, it has an old-school PS1-PS2 Look when you keep the pixelation on the highest setting (of course you can lower it when you have difficulty seeing anything with the filter). Me, who grew up with an PS2, love the old feel the game gives when playing on high pixelation. But without the pixelation, the game is a really simple, yet really good looking game that doesnt need high Triple A Standard Graphics to be an good game. The Atmosphere of the Game (when playing solo) immediately drags you into the feeling of dread with the excellent ambient and sound design. However with playing friends.. not as much but still quite chilling.

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]

Gameplay? Very simple like in Lethal Company. Collect Stuff, bring it to the Extractions and try to survive. What i love about this, you can use items you find to be able to damage the enemies and if lucky, kill them. You either play stealthy or you become a babarian.. which you can become either way when getting guns in the shop lol. When playing with Friends, the game turns quickly into an good shitshow. Accidentally smashing an cup to an friend and kill them. The amount of times i've laughed when me and my friends killed each other accidentally x'D.

[h3] Devs and Community [/h3] 

Devs? Amazing with regular videos of Game Updates, QnA's and even simply reacting to what the community creates. It's rare seeing Devs actually caring about their Playerbase and even join the fun the community creates. The Community is very creative with modding, how they play the game (that includes speedrunning and simply giving gameplay tactics and tipps) and even in the artistic ways. Dozens of many creative individuals in this community!

[h3] My Final Thoughts [/h3] 

Repo is one of my favorite Indie Multiplayer Game i regularly play with my friends, when they are available. Even when playing solo, the game is very fun. It can become frustrating in some cases tho. Aside, the community is very creative and the Devs full-on support mods. I can't wait for any future updates and hope the Devs have a lot of fun interacting with the community and keep giving the game updates! A solid 10/10 Game!

Repo isn't a friend-slop like SOME [i]others[i] (peak, content warning, etc.) aka its main gimmick doesn't revolve around being with friends, though if you want a happier experience instead of a scarier one, than having friends is a must. There's also consistent updates too where YOU the player can have an influence on the outcome of. The developers also regularly interact with the fanbase which is always a plus. 

Now I've only mainly played with friends or solo, rarely touching the online mode. So if you are looking for a review on the community or its toxicity level, this isn't the right review. Solo, on the other hand, is also amazing. Instead of the lightheartedness you'd expect you are greeted with a much more horrifying experience. [h1]My Therapist Now Charges Me Extra[/h1]
Listen up, prospective sembots. If you thought [i]Lethal Company[/i] was chaotic, wait until you have to haul a [b]fully physics-based, $40,000 vintage piano[/b] through a crumbling, monster-infested hospital with three other panicking robots. [b]R.E.P.O.[/b] isn't just a horror game; itâ€™s a masterclass in co-op therapy... the kind that gives you trust issues.

[h1]The Looting is the Laughing[/h1]
The central brilliance of R.E.P.O. is that every valuable object is a physics puzzle. You canâ€™t just pick up the goods; you have to carefully carry or drag them. This single mechanic turns every extraction into a synchronized tragedy. You spend half the run whispering about a monster's location, and the other half screaming because your teammate just clipped a massive statue on a doorway, sending it crashing into a wall and reducing its value to that of a damp sock.

The proximity chat, of course, enhances the absolute chaos. Hearing your friends' frantic shrieks fade into muffled desperation as they drag a precious bust across a creaky floor is comedy gold.

[h1]The Quota and the Quick Getaway[/h1]
The core loop is simple, but brilliantly stressful: Meet your profit quota, extract, and upgrade. The procedurally generated levels and unpredictable enemy placements ensure that no two runs are the same, keeping the anxiety levels high.

The true moment of terror isn't just seeing a monster; it's the realization that you have to [b]choose between profit and survival.[/b] Do you risk one more room for that ultra-valuable loot, or do you cut your losses and sprint to the exit. This choice, combined with the frantic, item-dropping dash, is what makes R.E.P.O. so intensely addictive.

[b]Final Verdict:[/b] If you want a co-op game that flawlessly blends genuine atmospheric horror with side-splitting, physics-based slapstick, [b]R.E.P.O. is the best chaos you can buy.[/b] Itâ€™s a perfect blend of tension, teamwork, and the hilarious sound of your priceless loot shattering into a million pieces.

It's one of my favorite games-- but I don't like the direction it's headed on the latest update. 

Loomâ€™s visual design is fantastic, but the gameplay design falls short. It removes stealth as a viable option, which was the core defensive mechanic and what made REPO unique in this genre.

When playing solo, you might as well restart your run, since hiding becomes impossible. Loom always knows where you are, relentlessly tracks you down, and either kills you outright or triggers other monsters. Even in the best scenarios, dealing with her feels tedious, and the game often throws in a second monster alongside her, making every encounter stressful and unfun.

Her health pool is absurd for how annoying she is to deal with. Six hundred HP in level 2 is ridiculous.

Stealth has always been a huge part of REPOâ€™s charm. The Duck and Huntsman combo was funny yet manageable; both were dangerous but could only find you through sight or sound, letting you strategically avoid them. Loom, on the other hand, makes zero noise, alerts every enemy to your location, one-shots you through doors, and completely removes the stealth element that made the game special. It ends up feeling more like Lethal Company than REPO.

Really good artistic design, fun lore and good overall design. Among other "friendslop" games it does stand out as much as it can among the countless other 1-4 player "go in and grab stuff" games. However it has a few serious flaws in its design.

Many monsters are functionally impossible to counter in a serious way unless you get decently far in, and they can do absolutely unmitigated damage to the items you've collected in the process. The choice often comes down to either losing outright or letting the monster destroy everything in your cart, which depending on how greedy you are (I myself am greedy on a biblical level, so put all my valuables in one cart) can make the round impossible to pass.

Alongside that there is a serious balance issue. There should not be the possibility of the "make noise or you die" monster coinciding with the "don't make noise or you die" monster in the same round, as a general example of the kind of problems that can arise. The number of enemies that spawn is very inconsistent and you will frequently find some monsters spawning in groups of 3 of the same monster, which for a monster like the gnomes can lead to literal armies of gnomes attacking you.

I know some people go doomguy and dominate high level runs where dozens of monsters might be attacking at all times, but I feel like a game like this really would shine if it focused less on spiky non-linear difficulty progression where a lot of the emergent behavior is how cRaAaZy the match gets when 3 psychics, 2 trudges, a scarecrow and now the flying kid on a tricycle that can fly around, stunlock you and kill 2 or more players in one activation. Instead I really wish, and hope to find in the future, that they would lean more in on both limiting the number of monsters and which ones can spawn simultaneously.

i have almost 200 hours on this game, it's one of my favorites to play with friends, especially in full lobbies. however, the new update has taken most of the fun out of it. tldr at the end.

i'm not opposed to new monsters or items, but dropping in a dozen new monsters at the exact same time with vastly different mechanics got overwhelming and way too difficult way too quickly. adding too many items to count with a significant number of them being large and hard to manage became just as overwhelming and obnoxious just as quickly.

not only were there way too many monsters and items to learn at the exact same time, they all have vastly different mechanics as previously mentioned. the main strategy for this game was stealth, and a lot of the new monsters, primarily the loom, completely eliminate stealth as an option. now you have enemies that are only survivable through stealth, you also have enemies where you can't utilize it at all. when two or more enemies with completely different survival strats are spawned on the same map, there's no plausible way to survive either of them unless you max out your upgrades and spend all your money on weapons that aren't even guaranteed to work.

 not only that, they're overpowered as hell. what's the point of giving us weapons and health upgrades if the monsters can one shot you either way? and that's assuming you can even afford the good stuff in the shop should they actually spawn in (which also isn't always likely). unless you're full clearing every single stage you're not guaranteed to get enough money for good weapons and upgrades if they're even in the shop. most of the new monsters are 200+ hp, even at level one which is absurdly unfair, especially for new players who don't even have a handle on the game's mechanics yet.

another issue which makes the addition of new enemies even worse is the spawn rates (including shop spawn rates). i've had up to 4 (maybe more, i honestly lost count) looms alone pop up in a run alongside numerous other enemies in levels as low as 4 or 5. the spawn rates need to slow down dramatically, especially with a total enemy respawn after last extraction is completed. i've full cleared 4 extraction runs just to get completely annihilated on my way back to the truck. the spawn rates in the shop are also wildly inconsistent and quite frankly get too expensive too quickly. all the big ticket items you can find in the game are either too large or fragile to get back to extraction. you have to move comically huge items across long stretches of the map just to lose half of its value if it taps the floor. at that point it's not even worth trying since it takes up too much space in extraction for the rest of your items that are actually worth anything. and if you don't break it, good luck fitting anything else that doesn't fit in your cart. sure, there's the indestructible drone, but that's also wildly expensive and needs to charge too frequently. 

overall, the monsters and items simply don't work as well as they used to. they're buggy, inconsistent, and less effective overall. monsters bug out with their spawns and pathfinding, shop items and upgrades simply don't help as much as they used to, and issues with the physics of the game have been getting worse. i can't even begin to tell you how much time i waste trying to organize my cart so an item doesn't decide to just roll out and break if i move it a few feet away from me. everything also likes getting horribly stuck on the stairs for some reason?

tldr; the new enemies are overpowered, annoying, infuriatingly difficult (especially at lower levels) with vastly differing mechanics, are hard to learn all at the same time, and have horrible spawn rates. the shop needs a complete overhaul of price and availability, with more consistency in both areas. the game has gone from fun and challenging, to rage inducing difficulty and grinding through every single level. too much is happening all at once and each new update reduces the overall quality of the game. the only way to make progress in this game is if you've been playing it since its first release and already had the skillset required. the game got harder, and not in a good way.

The balancing that needs to be done is not a matter of content or additions, but certain design choices and dilemmas the R.E.P.O. team is going to have to address
Currently the gameplay loop is heavily focused on a specific kind of janky difficulty, as opposed to exploiting that jank in order to create fun moments with friends using physics and emergent gameplay systems. Problem is, this difficulty isn't what makes this game fun. It's not the kind of harsh but fair learning curve you'd expect from a singleplayer roguelike, but instead a tedious and at times frankly inconsistent brutality that detracts from the main aspects of the experience and oftentimes prevents you from creating said fun moments.
It would greatly benefit from a light adjustment in tedious game elements, such as starting with no stamina and getting exhausted after a few seconds, only to regen in half a minute (you will die a lot, so this initial, pre-upgrades state is the one you spend the most time in) and focusing more on what players find light-hearted and amusing
Other adjustments that I could suggest involve scaling economy with amount of players, fixing hits through walls and doors, FOV slider, and SETTING A DIFFERENT KEY FOR SLIDE to prevent sliding into holes when you're trying to crouch

Ehn, I'm recommending against it specifically because the solo gameplay is no fun and the multiplayer is just 'ok'. My first time playing was with friends and we had a decently fun time. Definitely better than Lethal Company. So I decided to play solo similar to how I treated Lethal Company and while I'd say that Lethal Company's systems aren't very good at all and even less fun, this game is bad for other reasons.

Number 1 being sound design. I think some of the enemies in this game literally don't make sound, while others you can't hear until they're in the same room with you. It makes it so that how you deal with threats is almost purely reactionary. This is one place where Lethal Company wins out actually since it's sound design is surprisingly good and helps you assess threats before you even know they are there. In R.E.P.O. I am not even sure if there is an enemy spawn in sound and this is after I read the wiki. Maybe I just missed a mention there, but I went through and read about all the enemies after frustratingly dealing with them.

The physics based item collection is actually a great idea, but in practice... well it's still not bad. In multiplayer at least. In solo it feels good too, but only until an enemy decides to smash into the cart and oh, there goes all the valuables. So you have to always park the cart off to the side because the map design is...

Well really that brings us to level design. What level design? Like Lethal Company, it's just a lot of proc gen rooms. There's rarely anything of note in any particular room aside from the obvious items you're supposed to collect for one thing. But more importantly, the levels aren't really designed with the monsters in mind. Lethal company doesn't do it much better, but at least you can sorta predict what enemies you're dealing with. But regardless, the levels aren't actually made to house the monsters. Instead the levels exist and the monsters are made regardless of the levels. They're made to be 'dynamic'. Which means that on one hand, sometimes you will get lucky and there will be a pit and you can just nudge some enemies into the pit making them trivial. I don't understand why the rooms don't serve more function somehow. Aside from the occasional questionably useful laser beam that is. The stars of the show are always the monsters, but why does level design have to suffer as a result of that? And I say that in spite of the monster design being actually very poor. In multiplayer it's more like you're pest control and in singleplayer the monsters function horribly. I have hidden in a cabinet with the door closed and the headman just decided to see me anyway.

Under other circumstances though the level design will be a terrible hallway with no cover or anything. And you'd like to think that having hiding spots might be nice, but no, not really. A lot of the times the way the monsters detect you means that hiding spots are a noob trap. Really, if you don't know exactly how the monsters function, you might be signing your death warrant trying to hide under a desk. It really makes me wonder what is even the point. Are you meant to accidentally get screwed by the physics because 'lol funny physics!' and that's it? Cause I get it if that's the case, but then why even offer solo? Cause 'having the ability to play solo is better than nothing' right? That's the idea?

Yes and that's literally it. The game isn't made for solo it's made for multiplayer. But even with multiplayer it becomes kind of trivial. The only way the game can even challenge you is to overwhelm or cheat you. And by the time you're that good, you'll be bored of the game. Is this even meant to be horror?
